newsitem.title: MEXICO: Mexico Cetes rate ends up on month-end cash demand.
newsitem.headline: Mexico Cetes rate ends up on month-end cash demand.

text.p: Mexican overnight Cetes rates hung onto earlier increases to close up 70 basis points at 21.25 percent on Wednesday amid month-end demand for cash, dealers said.
Fixed-income analysts said dealing saw a tug-of-war between players with hefty liquidity positions, who wanted to jack up rates, and those who were long paper and wished to keep rates down.
"There was some upward speculative pressure, but it was offset by those holding paper, who did their best to hold rates down," one analyst said.
Dealers said rates also came under upside pressure from higher U.S. long bond yields and uncertainty ahead of forthcoming mid-term elections in Mexico.
Mexico will hold elections on July 6 to renew the entire lower house of Congress, one-quarter of the Senate, several state governor's and the first poll for Mexico City mayor in modern times.
The U.S. 30-year Treasury bond was off 19/32 to yield 6.74 percent in late trade.
The central bank drained 1.551 billion pesos from the market by assigning three direct Cetes sales and three repos.
Overnight rates on bank paper meanwhile rose 10 basis points to 22.15 percent.
Liquidity of 2.995 billion pesos was due to return to the system on Thursday from prior central bank operations.
